awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Inquiry into the Origins of Modern Human Distributions
awd_abstract_narration:
Since their discovery over 150 years ago, Neanderthals have captured the imagination of scientists and the general public. Researchers have been trying to understand their life ways and the processes through which they disappeared. Archaeology and the earth sciences are particularly well placed to address this dilemma because both investigate processes that act over deep time. Within this broad context, Dr. Jonathan Haws (University of Louisville) and Dr. Michael Benedetti (University of North Carolina Wilmington) will lead a three-year study of Neanderthal extinction and replacement by anatomically modern humans . The project brings together an international team to recover high-resolution archaeological, geological and paleoecological records from the excavation of Lapa do Picareiro, a cave in central Portugal. The project is designed to test whether or not differences in land use and diet allowed Neanderthals to survive in southwestern Europe longer than anywhere else. The ultimate goal is to determine why Neanderthals went extinct and were replaced by modern humans. The benefits of this project to society at large include a deeper understanding of human evolution, particularly the role played by environmental change, technology and diet choice. The project also offers scientific engagement and cultural enrichment for student participants who will join an interdisciplinary research team in an international setting. The PIs and their institutions have shown commitment to undergraduate research and demonstrated success in mentoring student research in previous NSF-funded projects. Many of the students involved in this project over the past 5 years have been first-generation college students from under-represented, working poor, and rural demographic groups in Kentucky and eastern North Carolina. Recruiting these students has the dual benefits of diversifying the field crew and enriching the educational experience for students who may not otherwise have opportunities for international travel or study. Building on the success of our previous work in Portugal, this project will also continue to generate scientific partnerships among American, Portuguese and Czech universities, creating new collaborative learning and research opportunities for students and faculty alike.

Lapa do Picareiro is a unique site, with about 10m of sediments spanning over 50,000 years. The sequence includes almost 2m of intact deposits dated between 30-42,000 years ago, making it an ideal place to track changes in paleoenvironments and human ecodynamics during the critical period of Neanderthal extinction and modern human colonization of Europe. The proposed methodology uses radiocarbon dating to establish age control, stone tool analyses to understand the decision-making of Paleolithic humans, animal bone assemblages to reconstruct paleoenvironments and understand Neanderthal and modern human diets, and sedimentological analyses to infer site formation processes and environmental context of human occupation. Taken together, the work will establish a complete paleoenvironmental and geoarchaeological chronology for the Middle-Upper Paleolithic transition at Lapa do Picareiro, providing critical context that is missing from many other sites in the region.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

The project findings to date have significantly altered our understanding of the spread of modern human populations across western Eurasia. We have discovered the earliest evidence for modern humans in western Iberia. Our excavation at Lapa do Picareiro revealed a new layer of human occupation with stone tool technology exclusively associated with modern humans. The layer is dated to about 40,000 years ago. Neanderthal occupation of the cave ended slightly earlier  around 42,000 years ago. The discoveries from Picareiro have important ramifications for our understanding of the process of modern human dispersal and replacement or assimilation of Neanderthal populations. Our work demonstrate a very rapid and unimpeded spread of modern humans across western Eurasia. Furthermore, our results support the notion that climate and environmental change played a significant role in this process.

Broader Impacts 

The main opportunities for professional development concern the advancement of women in STEM. One participant in the project completed her PhD at the Uniiversity of New Mexico and another is almost finished at Colorado State University.  Junior women colleagues were able to advance their careers through their work on the Picareiro coprolites. Additional professional development opportunities were provided to colleagues at the University of Oklahoma and University of Vienna.

The project provided valuable international travel, field experience, and laboratory training for undergraduate student participants from Kentucky and North Carolina. The students represented a diverse group that included several African-American, Latinx, and LGBTQ participants. In addition to direct work experience, student participants continue to contribute to our work as co-authors and co-presenters of publications and conference papers. Articles submitted this year include three graduate students as co-authors.

This project continues to encourage international collaboration between colleagues in the USA, Portugal, and Czech Republic. The cooperation of faculty and student assistants from multiple countries encourages cultural literacy and sensitivity among the participants. Students from Kentucky and North Carolina directly supported by the grant gained valuable international
field experience. Many of our student participants are first-generation college students and most had never traveled outside the United States before.

The publication of results in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences allowed for a wider impact across disciplines due to the Impact Factor and multidisciplinary readership of the journal. This was further promoted in global media distribution. Our results were covered by news outlets across Europe and Asia, including India, Vietnam and China, Oceania, Australia and New Zealand, Africa, including Nigeria, and South America, mainly Argentina and Brazil.


Last Modified: 09/27/2022
Modified by: Jonathan A Haws
